subject.name: Basic Electronics Engineering
subject.description: Introduction to fundamental electronic components and devices including diodes, transistors, operational amplifiers, and digital electronics. Emphasis on their characteristics, operations, and applications in modern circuits.
objectives: To understand the fundamental principles of semiconductor devices.
To analyze the behavior and applications of diodes and transistors.
To study operational amplifiers and their practical applications.
To learn the basics of digital electronics and Boolean logic.

units.title: Semiconductor Diode
topics: Energy band in intrinsic and extrinsic semiconductors
p-n junction under open circuit, drift, and diffusion current
Built-in potential, forward and reverse bias conditions
Temperature effects, static and dynamic resistance, breakdown mechanisms
Zener diode working and VI characteristics
Light emitting diode (LED), Photodiode, Solar cell

units.title: Diode Applications
topics: Numerical problems on rectifiers, filters, and Zener regulators

units.title: Bipolar Junction Transistor (BJT)
topics: BJT construction, symbols, and types (PNP, NPN)
Load line analysis and operating point
BJT as a switch and amplifier
CE amplifier with and without feedback

units.title: Field Effect Transistor (FET)
topics: JFET construction and principle of operation
Depletion and enhancement type MOSFET construction and operation

units.title: Operational Amplifier
topics: Block diagram and schematic symbol of an operational amplifier
Ideal and practical characteristics of op-amps

units.title: Fundamentals of Digital Electronics
topics: Binary addition using 1’s and 2’s complement method
Boolean algebra and De Morgan’s theorems
Simplification and realization of Boolean expressions using basic and NAND gates

suggested_books: Electronic Devices and Circuit Theory by Boylestad and Nashelsky, Pearson
Electronic Principles by Albert Malvino & Davis J. Bates, TMH
Digital Logic and Computer Design by M. Morris Mano, PHI
Electronic Devices and Circuits by David A. Bell, Oxford
Microelectronic Circuits: Theory and Application by Sedra and Smith, Oxford
